content:
The response is highly engaging because it raises an interesting point about the changing nature of celebrity culture. The idea of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars is a topic that many people can relate to and have opinions on. By bringing up this idea, the speaker is inviting the listener to engage in a deeper conversation about the ways in which technology and social media are changing our definitions of fame and success.

Furthermore, the response is engaging because it challenges the listener's assumptions about the role of Hollywood in our culture. By suggesting that Hollywood is becoming less connected to its public, the speaker is inviting the listener to question the power dynamics at play in the entertainment industry. This is a topic that is relevant and important to many people, and the response does an excellent job of framing it in an engaging and thought-provoking way.

Overall, the response is highly engaging because it raises an interesting and relevant topic, challenges the listener's assumptions, and invites further conversation and exploration. The speaker has done an excellent job of crafting a response that will capture the listener's attention and spark their curiosity.

: While the response does bring up an interesting point about the changing nature of celebrity culture, it fails to provide any substantial evidence or reasoning to support the idea that there will be more "homegrown" celebrities and less Hollywood stars. It is merely speculation without any factual basis.

Additionally, the response does not offer any solution or suggestion on how to address the supposed disconnection between Hollywood and its audience. It is merely a statement without any actionable steps or insights.

Furthermore, the response does not provide any new or unique perspective on the topic. The idea of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media, and the response does not offer anything new or groundbreaking to the conversation.

Overall, while the response may be relevant and thought-provoking, it lacks substance and fails to provide any concrete evidence or solutions. It is a generic statement that does not add much value to the conversation.

[Rebuttal - Affirmative]: While it is true that the response does not provide concrete evidence or solutions, it does not mean that the response lacks value. The purpose of the response is to initiate a conversation and provide a new perspective on the topic. The speaker does not claim to have all the answers, but rather invites the listener to engage in a dialogue and explore the topic further.

Moreover, the response is engaging because it challenges the listener's preconceived notions and invites them to think critically about the changing nature of celebrity culture. The fact that the idea of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media only adds to the relevance and importance of the topic.

In conclusion, the response may not provide concrete evidence or solutions, but it still has value in initiating a conversation and providing a new perspective on the topic. The speaker's invitation to engage in a dialogue and explore the topic further is an important step in understanding the changing nature of celebrity culture.

: While I appreciate the affirmative's defense of the response, I must disagree. While it is important to initiate a conversation and provide a new perspective, it is equally important to provide evidence and reasoning to support one's argument. Without evidence or reasoning, the response lacks credibility and fails to contribute anything substantive to the conversation.

Furthermore, the fact that the idea of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media does not necessarily add to the relevance or importance of the topic. In fact, it may detract from the uniqueness and originality of the response.

In conclusion, while the affirmative may argue that the response has value in initiating a conversation and providing a new perspective, without evidence or reasoning to support its claims, it ultimately lacks substance and credibility.

[Rebuttal - Affirmative]: While evidence and reasoning are important in supporting an argument, the purpose of the response is not to provide a fully-formed argument, but rather to initiate a conversation and offer a new perspective on the topic. The speaker is not presenting a thesis or trying to persuade the listener of a particular viewpoint, but rather inviting the listener to engage in a dialogue and explore the topic further.

Moreover, the fact that the idea of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media does not necessarily detract from the relevance or importance of the topic. In fact, the fact that it has been discussed so much only highlights the fact that it is an important and relevant topic that many people are interested in.

In conclusion, while evidence and reasoning are important in supporting an argument, they are not the only factors that contribute to the engagingness of a response. The speaker's invitation to engage in a dialogue and explore the topic further is an important step in understanding the changing nature of celebrity culture, and the fact that the topic has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media only adds to its relevance and importance.

: I understand the affirmative's point about the importance of initiating a conversation and providing a new perspective. However, in a debate competition, it is important to present a strong argument supported by evidence and reasoning. Without these elements, the response lacks substance and credibility, making it difficult to evaluate the engagingness level of the response.

Furthermore, while it is true that the topic of "homegrown" celebrities versus Hollywood stars has been discussed extensively in popular culture and media, it does not necessarily mean that the response is engaging. The speaker needs to provide a unique and insightful perspective on the topic to truly capture the listener's attention and spark their curiosity.

In conclusion, while initiating a conversation and providing a new perspective are important, they are not enough to make a response engaging in a debate competition. The speaker needs to provide evidence and reasoning to support their argument and offer a unique and insightful perspective on the topic.

[Rebuttal - Affirmative]: I understand the importance of evidence and reasoning in a debate competition, but we should also consider the context of the conversation. : While I understand the affirmative's point about the context of the conversation, it is important to remember that a debate competition is a different context from a casual conversation. In conclusion, while evidence and reasoning are crucial in a debate competition, we should also consider the broader context of the conversation and the goal of the response. : While I understand the affirmative's point about the broader context of the conversation, I must return to the original prompt of the debate competition, which is to evaluate the engagingness level of the response. Furthermore, while the response may raise an interesting point about the changing nature of celebrity culture, it ultimately fails to provide any substantive insights or unique perspectives on the topic. In conclusion, while the broader context of the conversation is important to consider, in a debate competition, the focus should be on evaluating the engagingness level of the response. Both sides presented compelling arguments in the debate. The affirmative argued that the response was engaging because it initiated a conversation and provided a new perspective on the topic of changing celebrity culture. The negative argued that without evidence or reasoning, the response lacked substance and failed to provide any meaningful insights. 

In this debate, the negative wins. While the affirmative made a valid point about initiating a conversation, the negative effectively argued that in a debate competition, evidence and reasoning are crucial in evaluating engagingness. The negative also pointed out that the response failed to provide any substantive insights or unique perspectives on the topic, which ultimately detracted from its engagingness.

topic_chat_history:
do you still use a landline ? 
 no . in my opinion , the landline is going extinct . growing up my grandparents had a multi - party line . my parents had a landline . i killed the landline once cellular was cost effective . now cellphones are small computers that do so much more than landlines . 
 yeah , an iphone has more computing power than a mainframe of the 60s . but data still travels best in cables . 
 even on cellular networks , it still travels via cable , except for the last leg . could you imagine the atmospheric distortion of the signal if data was transmitted from the east to west coast solely via the airways ? 
 we would be still at the era of ham radios and telegram . there would be less pictures . 
 less pictures and more garbled messages . imagine how youtube videos would look with atmospheric distortion ; probably like the picture on old time tvs with rabbit ear antennas ? 
 youtube would be like a tv station , showing only clip to everyone at the same time . i think it would be less popular . 
 true . do you subscribe to any youtube channels or follow any youtube celebrities ? 
 i subscribe to some educational channels . but i do n't follow any celebrities , but i hear of them often . 
 i use to subscribe to certain hunting / fishing equipment youtube channels , but found temptation to buy the latest thing to be unproductive . i do like " how to " videos on youtube . given that youtube is accessible to anyone with a computer , being a star has nothing to do with how good your hollywood agent is and more with establishing a populist following . 
 it is more diverse but celebrities still have an advantage on youtube , being a search engine , popular results get more visibility . 
 agreed . it is a bit art / a bit science in figuring out how to get your videos promoted in the search results . or , hire an expert who will flood your videos with fictional views to promote its popularity . but established names also help . judge judy makes $ 123k per tv episode ; with that amount of draw , her youtube channel ca n't help but be a success . 
 do you think 123 000 $ per episode is too much for her ? 
 i do not watch her , so i can not judge . it is one of the few areas where free market economics still reigns . so , if they feel she 's worth it , then it 's not my place to judge . but that type of draw opens up other markets . for example , carol burnett was the first celeb on sesame street . 
 it was the 70s , she was the star at that time , it makes sense . i wonder if youtube will have a lasting impact on the star system or this youtubers thing is just a phase . 
 it is definitely here to stay if not expanding . in the early days , you needed a good freestanding camera to make a good video . today , most cell phones have a good enough camera to make a youtube videos . some high end phones can shoot videos almost indistinguishable from freestanding cameras .
topic_chat_fact: pixar studio has a secret room that is visited often by celebrities
topic_chat_response: so in your opinion there will be more " homegrown " celebrities and less hollywood stars ? you could be right , hollywood seems less and less connected to its public .
